Dear Amy Harding:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12506 Education/vocational training/Employment
Section
Description (1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent living is
employed full-time, actively involved in job training or continuing
education, or a combination of employment and education
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth has not been participating in school since August 2022 and
instead stays at the home using marijuana. The agency has not
addressed this. Youth is also not employed.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 6/14/2023. He
reported he is concerned about Youth A’s placement because
they report minimal information about Youth A at court hearings.
Youth A has not been attending school since August, which the
agency did not report to the court until the most recent hearing. He
stated that the agency reported in court that Youth A was found
smoking marijuana in his room and that drugs were confiscated
from him, so he believes Youth A stays home all-day using drugs
rather than working or going to school.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed via video
conferencing on 6/1/2023 and reported she is the supervisor
assigned to Youth A’s case. She stated Holy Cross has case
2

responsibility for Youth A who is placed in one of the agency’s
Independent Living Plus (ILP) homes. She reported Youth A can
care for himself and has demonstrated independent living skills
adequate to live on his own. She reported he participates in
independent living skills training/activities on a regular basis. She
stated when he was initially interviewed for the program, he
declined the program as he was living in Kalamazoo and did not
want to relocate to Saginaw. FCS reported the home in which
Youth A was living in Kalamazoo was closing, so Holy Cross “did
a favor” for them and accepted Youth A into their ILP home.
FCS reported the agency staff initially attempted to enroll Youth A
in the local school district after moving to the ILP home, but they
required him to participate in a credit recovery program due to his
being behind in education. Agency staff did get Youth A into a
credit recovery program; however, that school required Youth A to
undergo searches and wanding upon arrival, which is a trigger for
Youth A. The school staff did come to an agreement that they
would not wand Youth A; however, they did it once after which he
refused to go back. Youth A does have the opportunity to attend
that school virtually, but he has not done so. FCS reported Youth
A in enrolled in school but has not attended since October of
2022.
Youth A does not currently have a job but has applied and
interviewed at several local businesses. He has participated in
MYOI and Michigan Works as well but is not currently doing
either. She stated the agency staff have had many conversations
with Youth A and several FTM’s to discuss the need for him to
attend school. FCS stated Youth A does not want to be in
Saginaw and has stated on multiple occasions that he will go to
school and work once he moves back to Kalamazoo where he
already has a job lined up.
FCS stated at Youth A’s last hearing, the Judge ordered that
Kalamazoo DHHS Monitor to find a placement for Youth A in
Kalamazoo. Youth A has an interview with an ILP home coming
up and there has also been a supportive adult identified with
whom Youth A might be placed with soon.
FCS reported that they are conducted an internal investigation
regarding the allegation that Youth A is using drugs instead of
going to school or working. She reported no staff have observed
him using any drugs or have caught him with any drugs on his
person. She stated there was another youth caught smoking
marijuana in the home and Youth A was present, but Youth A was
not observed to be using.
3

Independent Living Director (Director) was interviewed via
video conferencing on 6/1/2023. She reported Holy Cross staff
attempted to interview Youth A for their ILP program last summer,
but Youth A refused to participate. She stated Kalamazoo DHHS
“called in a favor” when Youth A’s placement was closing and
there were no other placements available for him in the area at
which time Youth A was interviewed again. Director stated Youth
A was appropriate for the placement based on the paperwork
provided by Kalamazoo DHHS and Youth A’s interview, so he was
accepted into the program in August of 2022. Prior to moving to
the ILP home, Youth A was attending school in Kalamazoo area.
Once moving to the home, an attempt was made to enroll him in
the local school district, but there was a concern related to his lack
of credits. He was enrolled in credit recovery program at a
different school; however, Youth A did not attend. He was then
enrolled in a different school. He dropped out of that school in
November of 2022 then re-enrolled in January of 2023; however,
he has not actively attended since October of 2022. She reported
Youth A has stated he will go back to school when he gets back to
Kalamazoo and refuses to attend local school.
Director stated Youth A is meeting the criteria to remain in the
program per the agency’s ILP contract as he is participating in
independent living skills, is enrolled in school, and is actively
seeking employment. She states Youth A has signed individual
independent living contracts agreeing to attend school or work.
She stated agency policy when a youth is not complying with their
individual contract is to hold a meeting with the youth to address
the concerns and hold an FTM/TDM to with the referring agency
to discuss the concerns and placement preservation during which
a plan is put into place. Agency staff evaluate the youth’s progress
toward the plan. Director stated there are not any timeframes
attached to the steps and there is nothing indicating at what point
a youth no longer becomes eligible for the program bases on their
failure to comply with school/work. She stated the agency staff try
to support the youth and make every attempt to avoid removing
them from the program as many of the youth have nowhere else
to go.
Director reported that Youth A spends a lot of time in his room
making music and paying video games but there have not been
any concerns about him using drugs in the home. She stated
minimal information is presented in the courtroom due to concerns
with the parents having all of the information; however, all of the
4

information needed is documented in the court report presented to
the judge.
Youth A was interviewed by phone on 6/2/2023. He reported he
has not gone to school “in a long time” but is starting summer
school as soon as he gets a start date. He stated that the ILP
home staff try to get him to go to school, but he hasn’t gone
because he was forced to move to the ILP home and does not
want to be there. He stated that he was participating in Michigan
Works at the ILP home until February or March and can’t
remember why he doesn’t anymore. He stated he has applied and
interviewed for jobs at several local restaurants including
McDonalds, Little Caesars, and Checkers, but has not been
offered a job. He stated he is working on his independent living
skills and that the staff are “doing their jobs” supporting and
encouraging him to attend school and work. Youth A denied any
drug use.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via video
conferencing on 6/5/2023.She reported Youth A began attending
school on 6/3/2023. She reported she has only been assigned to
the case since 4/1/2023 and Youth A has been enrolled in school
the whole time. She stated he has applied for jobs at Burger King,
McDonald’s, and KFC as well as other local businesses, but has
not been hired. She stated he was participating in Michigan Works
weekly, but quite because he thought the woman running the
meetings was racist. FCW stated Youth A is in compliance with
program expectations as he is enrolled in school and is applying
for jobs. She stated that there have been discussions at the
agency about Youth A’s appropriateness for the program based
on his refusal to attend school, but there is nowhere else for him
to go.
FCW reported Youth A wants to be in Kalamazoo and reports he
already has a job lined up at a friend’s restaurant in that area. His
Kalamazoo DHHS monitor continues to try to get him into ILP
homes in that area; however, there have been no beds available.
FCW was recently told a bed will be opening at an ILP home in
Kalamazoo in July and there has been a supportive adult in
Kalamazoo area who might be willing to take placement of Youth
A.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
- ILP Contract which indicates the youth agrees to be
employed/volunteering or attending a school or
5

vocational/employment program on a regular basis signed by
Youth A on 8/30/22, 1/26/23, and 4/25/23
- ILP Staff Supported Housing Participant Manual: Expectations
of Programming which states if a youth has not earned a high
school diploma or GED, they are expected to enroll in and
attend and education or vocational/technical program
throughout the year, signed by Youth A on 8/30/2022 and
4/25/2023
- Individual Curriculum Plans completed weekly with Youth A
documenting his efforts to locate employment, enrollment in
school, and school attendance record.
- School enrollment records:
Saginaw Covenant Academy 10/3/22-11/18/22
Saginaw Covenant Academy 1/4/2023 – current
- FTM/TDMs
o 8/30/2022 – Identified Youth A’s need to attend school
on a daily basis, signed by Youth A
o 1/26/2023 - Agreement to attend school at least 3 days
per week, signed by Youth A
o 4/25/2023 – Summer school recommended, signed by
Youth A
- Case Contacts
o Last case contact documenting Youth A’s school
attendance dated 9/22/2022
o Contacts with his assigned worker documented the
worker spoke to him about school attendance on an at
least monthly basis.
- Court Reports
o 12/28/2022 – Documented Youth A refuses to attend
school
o 1/20/2023 Documented the school Youth A will be
attending
o 2/13/2023 – Documented Youth A attending
5/10/2023 – Documented Youth A enrolled in school but not
attending
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as they ensure that Youth A is
enrolled in school and work with him to encourage attendance at
school. Additionally, he is actively seeking employment and has
participated in job training. His education status is reported to the
court.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living contract
Section (2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and the
Description social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and updated
at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy provided to the
youth.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation An updated Independent Living Contract and documentation that
the youth was provided with the updated contract is not
documented every 90 days.
Investigation DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
- ILP Contract signed by Youth A on 8/30/22, 1/26/23, and
4/25/23
- Email from Director dated 6/23/2023 stating Foster Care
Worker that was responsible for updating the ILP Contract
between 8/30/22 and 1/26/23 was separated from employment
due to performance issues and while Director believed an ILP
Contract was completed in November of 2023 due to all of the
other documents that would have been signed by the youth at
the same time being present in the file, the ILP contract wasn’t
located.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance due to there not being an
updated ILP Contract present in the file every 90 days.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
